name: 4-chloro-2,6-difluorobenzonitrile
Reason: The melting point of 4-chloro-2,6-difluorobenzonitrile is influenced by the benzene ring and the substituents attached to it. Starting from the base melting point of benzene at 5.5°C, each functional group will either raise or lower this temperature based on their individual properties. Fluorine atoms generally increase the melting point due to their high electronegativity and strong inductive effect, which enhances intermolecular forces; we can estimate this increase at about 20°C per fluorine atom, leading to a 40°C increase for two. The chlorine substituent, being larger and more polarizable than fluorine, would have a stronger van der Waals interaction, possibly contributing around 25°C due to its size and electronegativity. The nitrile group is known for being electron-withdrawing and highly polar, resulting in stronger dipole-dipole interactions, which would substantially raise the melting point; an approximate contribution could be 30°C. Summing up these adjustments, we obtain a combined estimated increase of 95°C from all substituents.
Test (Predicted reason):
The basic unit, benzene, has a melting point of 5.5°C. The presence of a chlorine atom generally increases the melting point due to increased molecular weight and polarizability, estimated at +20°C. The nitrile group (C#N) is highly polar and can engage in dipole-dipole interactions, which would significantly raise the melting point, estimated at +40°C. Fluorine atoms are highly electronegative and can participate in dipole-dipole interactions, which would further increase the melting point, estimated at +15°C for each fluorine atom. The cumulative effect of these groups is predicted to increase the melting point of benzene.
